Package com.vmpconsulting.training.demo

Class OOPSConceptsVersionOne

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.vmpconsulting.training.demo.OOPSConceptsVersionOne
  • public class OOPSConceptsVersionOne
extends Object
    This class, Welcomes everyone to the training session and sincerely makes an attempt to make everyones' life, easy while learning the basic concepts of OOPS and basic Java coding...

    A basic class, which would be the Entry point to rest of the Java classes, that are going to be discussed during the training session...

    As of the functionality, it simply receives the user name and the age and prints that out in the console... We'll make this more sophisticated, as we go along...

      • main

        public static void main​(String[] args)

        Basic HelloWorld function and nothing beyond it...
        Parameters:
        args - [] The Command line parameters, passed as an array of String...main(java.lang.String[])
        Throws:
        IOException - The thrown exception is not handled for the time being and is being rethrown for now... It would get handled in a better way, as we go along...
        See Also:
        getTheConsole()

      • getTheConsole

        public static BufferedReader getTheConsole()
        To keep things simple for the beginner, let us have a separate function, that returns the @see java.io.BufferedReader object, through which the console inputs could be read...

        For a while, not to worry about this method and it's implementation...:) Keep your heads light...You would get to know more on this, when the time is appropriate enough, as we go along...

        Important Note: As a new bee, to Java, do not worry to much about the way this method gets implemented...All you need to know is, you could call this method and could read the input from the user, through the console...In fact, this is exactly the definition of Abstraction , one of the very concepts of OOPS... Just know how to call a particular function, with appropriate parameters... Not to worry on the way the function gets implemented...

        In fact, the implementation of this method is another good example of a design patter called Singleton... But, just take a note for now and we would worry about the design patterns, at a later point of time...

        Returns:
        myReader, the BufferedReader object, that facilitates the reading of the input from the console...
        See Also:
        BufferedReader
